newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine Senate approves penalties for tax cheats.
newsitem.headline: Argentine Senate approves penalties for tax cheats.

text.p: The Argentine Senate on Wednesday approved a bill designed to crack down on tax cheats by allowing authorities to shut businesses that fail to issue receipts and fine consumers who do not ask for them.
Under the bill, which still must receive passage in the lower house of Congress, tax department inspectors will have the right ask consumers for their receipts when they leave shops.
Consumers caught without them may be fined from $150 to $2,500. Businesses and stores failing to issue receipts face fines of up to $30,000 and closure for up to 10 days.
Recepits will be required for purchases of more than $10.
The government estimates it loses about $20 billion a year, or half the national budget, in unpaid taxes. It hopes to have final approval for the bill before the end of the year.
